intro: Ceratocnemum rapistroides var. glaucescens, commonly known as the glaucous sand mat, is a low-growing, mat-forming perennial plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It features small, fleshy, blue-gray leaves that are covered in a waxy cuticle, which helps reduce water loss in its harsh environment. The plant produces tiny, yellow flowers that bloom in the spring, adding a subtle floral display to the landscape. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in disturbed or sandy habitats. Due to its drought tolerance and ornamental appeal, it is sometimes cultivated in xeriscapes and native plant gardens.
